"taxes don't fund spending"

"deposits don't constrain lending". 

Exaggerations like that....

@dandolfa @GeorgeSelgin Seems like a lot of this discussion is people talking past one another. 

It's okay to say deposits fund loans (they add to revenue in numerous ways) and loans create deposits (banks don't necessarily need deposits to make loans).

@0InterestMath Interest isn‚Äôt just an exchange across time. It is a change in the discount rate across time. It‚Äôs a non-linear relationship, but it‚Äôs not a net inflationary impact at any temporal period.

@0InterestMath Icarus is a great example. Flying has asymmetric risks as you move higher. It doesn‚Äôt mean flying at 1 foot has no risk. 

Rate hikes are a scale of relative disinflationary risk. They‚Äôre not inherently inflationary.
@CarlitosMMT It‚Äôs amazing that MMT has gotten everything wrong about inflation in the last 2 years and you still go around calling other people obtuse. ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

Your inflation theory is totally incoherent, inconsistent and the last 2 years have exposed its flaws.

It‚Äôs okay to just admit MMT contradicts itself here.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm with Ron‚Äù

@CarlitosMMT What‚Äôs mischaracterized? She endorses Ensana‚Äôs debt deflation narrative even tho she consistently says that higher rates cause inflation‚Ä¶.

@DavidMarilley @choffstein @breakingthemark Becomes a really messy calculation when you start adding all non-financial assets. @MebFaber GAA is a good approximation but I don‚Äôt think it does FX hedging. 

I tend to just do stocks/bonds. For now‚Ä¶

@DavidMarilley @choffstein @breakingthemark Never understood what that terms really means. Everyone‚Äôs active so everyone has to be tactical. Eg, 60/40 is called passive, but massively deviates from actual global stock/bond market caps over time. It‚Äôs extremely ‚Äútactical‚Äù.

@choffstein @breakingthemark I mean, I understand the beauty in the simplicity of a fixed weight rebalancing methodology, but a multi asset portfolio has wildly different market cap weights every year (mainly because the stocks boom/bust). But it ends up being a huge active deviation from actual MC.

@choffstein @breakingthemark That‚Äôs the essence of my countercyclical indexing strategy. You shouldn‚Äôt rebalance back to a fixed weight. You should rebalance components based on expected returns. 

I‚Äôve never understood why 60/40, eg, rebalances back to a fixed weight when its relative market cap changes.

@philbak1 @77cyko @EconomPic Same story with Lance Armstrong. They were so much better than the other guys on an clean/even playing field that once they started cheating it became obviously unfair. Plus they were jerks about the whole thing....

The worrisome thing is that this real estate downturn has only just begun. Maybe it doesn‚Äôt get too bad? I don‚Äôt know. But the Fed has made it clear they‚Äôre not going to ride to the rescue with lower mortgage rates any time soon. 

So it‚Äôs gonna be a grind in any case.

I think this has a high probability of being a secular bear mainly because the underlying economic event here is a real estate downturn. 

Real estate operates with long and slow cycles because it‚Äôs an inherently long process (building homes takes a long time, I should know!) https://t.co/Dy98B8XAJ2

The difference between a secular bear market & a bear market correction is that the secular bear coincides with a real economic event. 

Garden variety market corrections tend to be short as the market gets a whiff of real economic weakness that turns out to be a false alarm. https://t.co/mINIPS168C

Not only one of the greatest scenes in the history of cinema, but also a great lesson in how/why diversification works.

Eg, professional bodybuilders break the law because the bodybuilding federations give them no choice about ‚Äúhonor‚Äù and ‚Äúintegrity‚Äù. It was the same exact thing with MLB in the 90s.

@TheStalwart @JoMicheII @tymoignee Where MMTers go really wrong on all this is that they promote the equivalent of a sinking corporation needing only to issue more shares to fund more investment (with the assumption it would be "self funding" and right the ship). 

This could be right. But it's usually very wrong.

@TheStalwart @JoMicheII @tymoignee Fiscal policy impacts the demand for money the same way share issuance impacts the demand for equities. 

A corp theoretically has infinite shares to issue just like a govt theoretically has infinite money. But supply is constrained by demand tho (which is reflected in prices).

@clvlandcurmudgn Yeah, it‚Äôs interesting to think about because the rebal back to 60 means you often rebal back to a really risky 60 whereas something closer to market cap would expose you to less equity risk on average (and presumably a superior rebalancing bonus).

@ChrisFryettMill @christine_benz "Optimal" IMO needs to meet planning needs AND behavioral needs. Financial planning is nuanced and while "simple is better" sounds great in theory it often isn't consistent with planning or behavior.

On the other hand, if the Fed offered to buy bags of dirt from anyone willing to give them to the Fed that would be a trade of net new deposits for non-financial assets.

It's especially interesting in the context of what they own on that balance sheet.

This creates an asset allocation that is not just seeking optimal return per unit of risk, but optimal return per unit of risk across TIME. 

My hope is this increases certainty, improves planning and reduces behavioral biases. 

I hope you find it helpful!

This image gives a good idea of the major asset classes and what their "duration" might look like. 

One cool aspect of this is it can be applied to any asset AND any strategy. https://t.co/7TpIMLnD2h

I've quantified the "duration" for ALL asset classes using an approach similar with William Bernstein's "point of indifference". 

The goal is to create a framework  similar to bond laddering where we apply specific asset classes to specific time horizons & increase certainty.

I wrote about the MoM vs YoY inflation debate and why we shouldn't get overly excited about headline monthly CPI changes.  

https://t.co/7IOm0naEob

@WoodsfordSquare @johbergs_stat The BLS wrote an entire research piece describing how 12 month time series provide the "best overall" measure of current and future inflation. 

https://t.co/jtv4z9ioaj https://t.co/ArURTmm0Re

@WoodsfordSquare @johbergs_stat That's not true at all. The longer-term trend in the data series is why the Fed is so worried that inflation is entrenched. 

They really don't care if inflation is flat for one month when the 12 month trend is 8.5%. It has no impact on their policy stance.

@bordache @TheStalwart Yes, which reinforces the whole point of how noisy one month data is.

The reason the BLS uses core inflation is because items like energy and food are very noisy across single months. Hence why the one month reading isn't as useful as some people here want to claim....

@WoodsfordSquare @johbergs_stat Yes, they watch the monthly data to see if it turns into a more useful SERIES of long-term data. One month isn't a trend and is largely noise. The BLS is very specific that longer-term data series are more useful and important.

@sfrancisatx @sebastiangood Yes, the proper context is to provide both YoY and MoM with the emphasis on the YoY. Instead, some people in this thread are referring only to MoM as if it's the more important context. It's not.

@sfrancisatx @sebastiangood The point is that they want to see a more reliable long term trend. One month is very noisy, largely meaningless and the BLS specifically states that longer term series (like a 12 month series) is ‚Äúbest‚Äù. https://t.co/qhGk38jE65
@johbergs_stat Yes, they want to see that the longer-term trend in SEVERAL monthly readings is declining. One month is meaningless. Many months are more meaningful‚Ä¶.
@Jesse_Livermore Pffft. You're looking at days? Inflation also hasn't risen in the last 5 minutes!

@mr_victor7 It's not that they don't care at all. It's that the relative importance of the meaningful upward long-term trend is more important than a one month flat reading. 

https://t.co/qM0VMSawdg

In short, one month of FLAT prices is not a very statistically meaningful data point. Is it reassuring? Yes! And if we get several more (or negative) then that will be even more reassuring. 

But let's not overstate the importance of a very short trend.
Now, if we got a -10% collapse in prices next month (reminiscent of something like 2008) then the weighted ONE MONTH change might be very useful and important.

For example, looking at the actual data we can see that the data has appeared to start moderating SEVERAL times in the last few years if you only looked at the short-term trend. When, in reality, the broader long-term trend remained flat/up. https://t.co/L5bVe232Nr

On this *very silly* MoM vs YoY inflation debate:

It's the weighted average change that matters most. Eg, one month of flat prices is relatively unimportant in the scope of the broader long-term trend.

@dopamine_uptake The model is inherently long-term (several years at minimum). It doesn't predict short-term counter-trend moves in the market, nor is it designed to try to do so....

I also wouldn't describe it as "very bearish". It's underweight equities....

@TheStalwart @mark_dow They're not "only" watching YoY. But when it comes to MoM vs YoY they care MUCH, MUCH more about the weighted YoY long-term trend as it reflects broader and more reliable data about the trend.

@TheStalwart Yeah, they want to see ‚Äúseveral months‚Äù of DECLINING inflation data. The weighted change is what‚Äôs important. One month of flat prices is statistically unimportant in the scope of the broader trend‚Ä¶.

@mark_dow @TheStalwart The weighted average change matters. A flat MoM reading is statistically meaningless in the scope of the broader upward trend. Sure, if we get several meaningfully negative readings that will be important. We‚Äôre not there.
@mark_dow @TheStalwart Nah. I don‚Äôt think one month of data changes their policy stance at all.

@robert19pearson @GeorgeSelgin I'm not sure how you'd quantify "real resources", but I'd certainly argue that the private sector creates real resources that fund govt spending.

@robert19pearson @GeorgeSelgin If you swap out the word "capital" for "resources" across the MMT literature then it becomes clear that the govt operates like a bank with a non-legally-binding capital constraint.

@robert19pearson @GeorgeSelgin I am talking about ALL money creation. The govt has a non-legally-binding capital constraint. 

Govt spending is ultimately constrained in real terms by the amount of capital that exists in the domestic economy.

@robert19pearson @GeorgeSelgin If you have equity in your house (RHS) then you can use that equity as collateral to obtain funding for a home equity line of credit. 

Real assets are the main source of collateral for all new funding.

@robert19pearson @GeorgeSelgin Yes, it's correct to say that the govt doesn't need to "pay for" every dollar it spends by obtaining an existing dollar. But it's also wrong to say that taxes don't fund spending. 

MMT takes a similarly misleading narrative except in the opposite extreme.

@robert19pearson @GeorgeSelgin All those assets comprise the real resources that fund all of the balance sheets. If I build a house from nothing that real asset/resource can be used as collateral to fund future spending.

None of this is to say that the US economy isn't bloated or that the US govt should keep spending wildly, but the idea that the US economy as a whole is "insolvent" is simply preposterous, fails basic accounting and basic math.

4) Of course, the real kicker with "unfunded liabilities" is that they're not guaranteed. The US govt can decide, tomorrow, that it's unaffordable and the problem simply disappears with the stroke of a pen.

3) If we look at "unfunded liabilities" we should also consider "unfunded assets". 

Eg, the IER estimates that there are $160T-$200T in recoverable fossil fuels on govt lands. Hey look ma, we're suddenly "solvent". 

You can see how this is somewhat still of course, but still.

2) While the liabilities here are projected infinitely the assets are not. 

Eg, If we project the assets (Kim cites $193T) growing at JUST 3% over 75 years then they're almost 2 QUADRILLION.

Bad math and "Unfunded liabilities" is doing *A LOT* of heavy lifting here. 

1) $169T is based on the "infinite horizon" method which projects the liabilities *infinitely* into the future. Other methods (such as the 75 year method) range from $20-$65T.

#2 creates an interesting problem in CPI data because it result in rents being understated during recessions (doesn't capture higher turnover) and muted during booms (vice versa). 

Excellent paper on this: 

https://t.co/536ftELdbo

2) Rents generally lag (if at all, eg rent control). CPI measures this biannually to get a broader sample. So, your neighbor rents a new apartment for 20% more than you, but you're locked in at a lower rate. *Your* CPI didn't rise as much as your neighbor's.

Main reason for muted rental prices in the CPI is:

1) CPI adjusts rent to account for utilities (because rental contracts often include utilities). Recent huge jumps in utility costs are backed out so the CPI doesn't double count utility costs.

Lotta talk about how CPI should be higher because of rents. It's true and the BLS knows this. 

But the story is *much* more complex than that....

@PoorAtAuberge @TheStalwart I haven't studied that proposal. 

I was just explaining what realized capital gains are.

In short: 

An inverted curve doesn't automatically mean the world is ending or that recession is imminent, but it does tell us that the probability of the economic slowdown is rising. 

Stay tuned. A much deeper inversion would warrant much more attention.

One thing that the curve appears to be signaling is that there's a rising risk of a Fed policy mistake. Ie, the market is less worried about inflation while the Fed is *potentially* reacting too much too fast (or too late).

My personal view: developed economies are highly interest rate sensitive as they're so financialized. 

So the yield curve is a coincident indicator that tells us a lot about the probability of future growth. But it's not an on/off growth switch.

3. There is mixed evidence on this indicator's utility outside of the USA though. See:

https://t.co/iKno6333CV

4. Curve inversions usually precede disinflation (falling rates of inflation).

The yield curve has officially inverted. Some thoughts on what this might mean: 

1. Yield curve inversions have preceded every recession in the last 60 years. 

2. Recession usually occurs 12-18 months after an inversion.

@honest_math @EconomPic @gostr84ward @choffstein Yeah, your balance is f$cked in a year like 2008 no matter what. But if you can choose to sell the bonds only the likelihood that your balance comes back into line is higher (because you own more stocks than you otherwise would).

@EconomPic @gostr84ward @choffstein Yes. When you blend the stocks/bonds in a single fund you don't create liquidity because the stocks dominate the negative volatility. So if you needed liquidity in 2008 you were taking a principal loss because you can't choose to sell just the bonds in the fund.

@EconomPic @gostr84ward @choffstein Yeah, that's the main risk in holding a single 60/40 fund. It creates liquidity risk because it's homogeneous. @EconomPic @gostr84ward @choffstein Maybe I'm still scarred from 2008, but I owned a "safe dividend" fund in 2008 that was down 60%.

@gostr84ward @EconomPic @choffstein Same difference. Stocks can create liquidity risk in a portfolio specifically because they can impose a principal loss on an investor who needs liquidity during a drawdown.

@IgorRut @MomentumP500 @Rick_Ferri It could be assuming those were the only two portfolios in the world and that they perfectly mirrored one another. 

In reality there are millions of smaller "indexes" that make markets around some of these big fish.

@IgorRut @MomentumP500 @Rick_Ferri The point is, for an index fund like the S&P 500 to be able to maintain its "index" it must have non indexing counterparties to buy/sell whatever doesn't match the index. 

An index needs a more active subset of market makers to make its index even work.

@MomentumP500 @Rick_Ferri No, it's impossible. Eg, everyone cannot hold the S&P 500 because in order for the S&P 500 to turnover to match its index it must actively sell holdings or quantities that no longer match the index. Those buyers do not index or do not comprise one equivalent index.

@MonetaryWonk @mikealfred @Rick_Ferri If this were true then indexed firms would exhibit higher survivorship bias as indexing has grown. 

But the exact opposite has occurred! https://t.co/ZppYYFVLaX

@MomentumP500 @Rick_Ferri When a mutual fund buys stocks they obtain cash from shareholders and sell that cash to traders who sell them shares. 

All cash (and financial assets) are held by someone at all times. Indexers cannot all hold the same portfolio!

@MonetaryWonk @mikealfred @Rick_Ferri Yes, but even in that case there's a market maker and stock picker trading shares so there's liquidity for the indexer at some point in the transaction chain. 

Indexing doesn't make markets less efficient. It makes them deeper, more liquid and more efficient.

@mikealfred @Rick_Ferri That's the strange thing about passive critiques. Someone must be doing the analysis on the other side of the trade to make a market for the passive investor to even buy the index fund. 

That's why I hate this binary passive vs active distinction.

@Rick_Ferri The weird part about this narrative is that everyone cannot, by definition, hold index funds. 

If you buy an index fund you're selling your cash which means someone else, by definition doesn't hold the index fund.... https://t.co/ThGiwi8Zl5

@dandolfa @dsquareddigest @Capricciola @StevenHailAus @MpeterF No, I *think* we're agreeing that banks do in fact intermediate savers and borrowers in the way they use deposits to fund loans. 

Loanable funds is wrong in a strict sense, but it doesn't mean banks (or govts) don't fund their balance sheet expansions.

@dandolfa @dsquareddigest @Capricciola @StevenHailAus @MpeterF In an endogenous money model "funding" is all about having credit to endogenously expand the balance sheet. 

Deposits enhance credit by increasing net income. Therefore, they absolutely fund the bank's balance sheet expansion.

@MonetaryWonk @dandolfa @dsquareddigest @Capricciola @StevenHailAus @MpeterF Yeah, but it's a semantic way to frame it. 

It's similar to the way MMT says "taxes don't fund spending". Sure, taxes aren't necessary, but they allow a govt to leverage their balance sheet more so they're a hugely beneficial part of balance sheet funding.

@dandolfa @dsquareddigest @Capricciola @StevenHailAus @MpeterF A depositor. Eg, you might bank with Bank of America and hold deposits with them. They want your deposits not only because they're a cheap liability, but also because they can charge you other fees (ATM fees) or sell you other products (mortgages, asset management, etc).

@dsquareddigest @dandolfa @Capricciola @StevenHailAus @MpeterF I don't think this is right. Deposits have a huge multiplier effect across bank balance sheets mainly because they're inexpensive liabilities that usually allow the bank to tap the client for other high revenue sources (mortgages, fees, asset management, etc).

@dandolfa @Capricciola @StevenHailAus @MpeterF Banks need inexpensive liabilities. Deposits are the least expensive liability. 

So sure, they might not "need" deposits, but they definitely want them to fund their balance sheet.

@Capricciola @StevenHailAus @dandolfa @MpeterF The key point is that banks accumulate deposits to fund their loan books and leverage a more profitable capital structure. 

So yes, banks absolutely draw on deposits to make new loans even if they don't lend deposits dollar for dollar.

@Capricciola @StevenHailAus @dandolfa @MpeterF A bank is profitable when its assets earn more than its liabilities. Deposits are an inexpensive liability and when they can't obtain deposits their capital structure quality declines. Hence, banks need deposits to fund their operations even if they don't lend deposits.
@dandolfa @Capricciola @StevenHailAus @MpeterF I said they add to capital by making the bank more profitable. They're an inexpensive liability.

@Capricciola @StevenHailAus @dandolfa @MpeterF Deposits are the least expensive form of capital funding in the banking system so deposits add to capital and fund loans by making the bank balance sheet more profitable. 

A bank that can't obtain deposits has less credit because it must draw on other sources of funding.

@ChrisRondinelli High inflation. We're seeing the inflation constraint in the way the current inflation nuked Build Back Better.

In short, US govt debt charts look scary, but in the broader context (when compared with total assets) they don't look as scary. 

So the key is the inflationary impact, which, IMO looks more like a one-off COVID response surge that will subside with time.

All of this means the current inflation scare isn't likely to persist and that the govt will likely keep rates low by historical standards. 

So, the plan is:

1) Less fiscal policy going forward.
2) Low interest rates. 
3) More QE.

I've previously talked about why hyperinflation is a low probability outcome mainly because this one time surge in govt spending won't overcome the secular inflation headwinds in the long run:

1) Demographics
2) Technology
3) Globalization
4) Inequality

https://t.co/5kKPRzQAU8

MMT people say some whacky stuff on occasion and have had no viable response to the current inflation, but one thing they get absolutely right is that a large wealthy economy is constrained by inflation, not solvency.

But what the govt giveth the govt will soon taketh away.

Here's the fiscal policy contribution to GDP in the past and coming years. https://t.co/QT9Qv6fZGk

This is especially true of govt spending since so much of govt spending has a negative net present value. 

And we've seen the huge inflationary impact of govt spending in recent years. 

Much more on understanding govt liabilities here:

https://t.co/AFKib8I4aG

This doesn't mean liability creation is always good. It's only good when there's a multiplier effect that results in real resource creation. 

Eg, borrowing at a low rate to build a new innovative company is good, borrowing at a high rate to consume goods could be bad.

First, aggregate sectors don't "pay back" debts. The liabilities almost always grow. But so do the assets! 

Individuals, eg, pay back their debts. Individuals, in the aggregate, do not all pay back their debts. 

The key is whether net wealth grows, which it has in the USA. https://t.co/KWpxc3Dz3l

@soloprosperity @AdamSinger @TurnerNovak The real cost of funding govt liability issuance is the rate of inflation. So yes, govt debt issuance isn't an issue assuming it doesn't cause high inflation.

This is not to imply that debt is good or bad. Again, it depends. But we shouldn't always assume debt is bad. 

More on this here. I hope it helps. 

https://t.co/AFKib90doO

A HOA is essentially a small govt. It can be awful. It can be great. The liabilities of a HOA are, in the end, the liabilities of all the homeowners and funded by homeowners even if you don't see those liabilities on your personal balance sheet.

The govt is particularly messy because they issue a lot of assets/liabilities for public purpose (which doesn't always have a real economic gain in the same way that building a house does). 

I like to think of the govt like a money issuing HOA (homeowners association).

Debt (or asset/liability issuance) is used to fund all sorts of things including consumption, investment, innovation, etc etc. Whether this adds to aggregate assets and real wealth in the long-run is a complex issue. It can be good, it can be bad.
The flip side of that relationship is financial assets. Which also usually rise in the long-run. https://t.co/6xkBTSvy5j

In the aggregate we should expect financial liabilities AND assets to rise over time. In fact, we need them to. This is why total debt always rises in the long-run. See, eg, household debt: https://t.co/7z1EJXOz27

One of the most common fallacies of composition in finance is the "debt is bad" narrative. 

Debt reflects the relationship of a financial liability AND its financial assets. Financial assets and liabilities are not inherently good nor bad. *It depends*. https://t.co/LFl4sbTSit

@AdamSinger @TurnerNovak I guess this the part where I explain that financial liabilities are just the flip side of financial assets.  :-)

"Solving" the national debt removes the assets AND the liabilities.

@686Prism Yeah, they're more like the source of the liquidity and the independent utility companies maintain the piping, etc.

If you can figure out how and how much a govt should spend to optimize economic output you'll win a Nobel Prize and probably just about every other award possible. 

:-)

#1 is VERY important. 2008 proved this as our banking system nearly caused a much broader economy calamity. 

#2 is controversial and IMO not as effective as many believe. So it becomes a debate about how much the govt should spend.

So, the "right" amount of Fed printing is:

1) Enough for banks to function smoothly.

2) A response to govt spending and how effective you think asset swapping is in stimulating the economy....

The more important aspect of QE (& why pandemic QE appeared more inflationary than '08 QE) is fiscal policy (govt spending). 

When the govt runs a deficit they're INCREASING total assets in the private sector. When Fed does QE they're changing the composition of those assets.

The Fed also prints reserves during QE. This is just swapping T-Bonds for reserve deposits. Like changing a savings account into a checking account. 

A new deposit enters the private sector and a T-Bond leaves the private sector (no change in net assets).

At its core the Fed is just an interbank clearinghouse. 

This means most of the "printing" they do does not even enter the real economy. Most of it is printing enough interbank reserves so banks can clear payments between themselves.

"What's the right amount of Fed printing?"

@consequencerisk @netbacker @maxamillianz @flyingfox44 @wbmosler Yes, but the point is you run out of non govt demand for the money. By the time you're printing the 100 trillionth dollar the demand is gone which is functionally equivalent to a funding collapse.

@TheStalwart Also, if QE was stimulative in the way people assume it would cause rates to go UP, not down. That's literally the whole point on IOER - so that the Fed can raise short term rates when/if QE causes long rates (and inflation) to rise.

@maxamillianz @netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler Yes, all else equal, I think another year of 3T deficits would cause higher inflation which would result in the need for lower budget deficits in 2023/24.

@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler I'm just trying to explain the concept. 

The USA has the same funding constraint (non govt demand for their assets) that Argentina does. The USA has more demand for their assets, that doesn't mean they don't rely on non govt demand for their assets to fund spending.

@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler It's not voluntary. That's the point. The rate of inflation is largely driven by non govt demand for money and directly influences how much the govt can spend. 

Saying "the govt can print money" does not mean they always have the same degree of funding capacity.
@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler Semantics aside, my point is inflation is a funding constraint.

@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler Do you think the US govt can run 3T deficits for the next few years without exacerbating inflation?

@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler This is as true in the USA as anywhere. Today, eg, the US govt has less funding capacity than it did in 2020 because more govt spending risks causing higher inflation (reducing demand for money).

@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler Demand is an indication of funding capacity. A govt with high inflation (low demand for money) cannot fund as much spending as it can when inflation is low.

@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk @wbmosler There isn't "always demand for govt debt".

Very high inflation is specifically an environment where demand for govt liabilities is low.

@netbacker @flyingfox44 @consequencerisk Read more carefully. 

The govt funds bond issuance by issuing a bond to a deposit holder. The deposit holder gets the bond, the govt redistributes their deposit. The bond is a net asset and reflects the balance of taxes vs spending.

@flyingfox44 @netbacker @consequencerisk A deficit redistributes deposits from bond buyers to recipients of govt spending AND results in new bonds held by the bond buyer.

This is "asset printing" if we want to call it that.
@netbacker @consequencerisk The govt taxes existing deposits. Redistributes them into other people's accounts when they spend.
@netbacker @consequencerisk In FY 2021 the US govt spent 6.82T. Of that 4.05T was redistributed from existing assets and 2.77T was newly created assets.

@GeorgeSelgin @karlbykarlsmith Eh, I'd say raising rates from 0% is a policy choice, whereas the 0% rate itself is an operational fact that results from having a closed interbank system.

@GeorgeSelgin @karlbykarlsmith Because a banking system with reserves will try to get rid of those reserves. But it's a closed system so the rate must naturally fall to 0% when the banks try to get rid of the reserves....

@GeorgeSelgin @karlbykarlsmith I don't think it's a paradox. QE just drives the overnight rate to its natural rate of 0%. 

So, if they were doing something else to keep rates up (like a corridor) then QE just offsets that policy position back to its neutral/natural position.

@GeorgeSelgin @karlbykarlsmith I wouldn't say it cannot have an impact. I would say it's expected impact is overstated.
